awd_titl_txt: Assessing the effects of carboxylated amino acids and polysaccharides on the fluid-calcite element partitioning
awd_abstract_narration:
Many marine organisms build elaborate skeletons and shells made of carbonate minerals. Organic molecules such as amino acids and carbohydrates play important roles in regulating the structure and texture of these carbonates. Recent studies show that certain amino acids enhance magnesium uptake in carbonates and thereby influence the overall chemical composition. It is likely that these organic molecules influence the uptake of other elements as well, though this idea has not been tested. Using carefully controlled laboratory experiments, this study will investigate the effect of organic molecules on the abundance of several trace elements in carbonates. Trace element compositions of marine biogenic carbonates are widely used as tools ("proxies") to infer the temperature and the chemistry of ancient seawater, though it is known that biological processes also influence the shell chemistry. The outcome of this study will improve the reliability of trace element proxies by providing insights into biological controls on carbonate formation. This should advance our ability to reconstruct the dynamics, biology, and chemistry of the oceans in the past, which is a key to understanding the Earth's climate system. The research outcomes should be also relevant to other areas, such as removal of toxic heavy metals from the environment, engineering of new synthetic materials for industrial purposes, and geological CO2 sequestration. 

Based on inorganic calcite precipitation experiments using a pH-stat system, the research team will determine if and by how much element/Ca ratios in CaCO3 and precipitation rates depend on the types and concentrations of organic molecules at a constant saturation level. The research team will also address whether such effects are due to modulation of precipitation rates (kinetic effects) or due to direct molecular/ionic interactions by performing additional experiments using a known calcite precipitation inhibitor. This project provides support for an early-career investigator as well as research opportunities for undergraduate students at the University of Hawaii, where the student population has an exceptionally diverse ethnic background.

por.por_cntn:
Many marine calcareous organisms, such as corals and foraminifers, produce shells or skeletons made of CaCO3. Also incorporated in these CaCO3 are trace amounts of dissolved elements present in seawater. Critically, the extent of incorporation of such trace elements into CaCO3 depends on the physical/chemical state of seawater. For instance, magnesium (Mg) concentration in CaCO3 correlates strongly with temperature. From this relationship, in theory, we can reconstruct the past changes in the ocean temperature by quantifying Mg in calcareous fossils (so called paleo-proxies). Such information will be the foundation for testing climate models and placing realistic predictions for future climate change. However, extracting the environmental/climatic signals from these proxies can be challenging due to various complications. One example is so-called vital effects, or apparent organismal controls on trace element uptake during calcification, for which organic matrix made of bio-molecules such as proteins and amino acids is thought to play important roles.

This research has examine the effect of carboxylic amino acids on the incorporation of trace elements into calcite based on careful laboratory experiments. While some experimental data are still being carefully analyzed, we found enhancement of magnesium and strontium incorporation by aspartic and glutamic acid. This research additionally examined the controls on the incorporation of boron and lithium into CaCO3, which have been increasingly recognized as useful paleo-proxies for the acidity of the ocean and strength of continental weathering (and thus for long-term global carbon cycling). Our experimental results demonstrating strong kinetic controls (i.e., CaCO3 precipitation rate) for incorporation of both elements have played an instrumental part in developing a state-of-the-art surface kinetic model.

The novel dataset generated in this research will advance our understanding on the mechanism of vital effects by providing new insights into the roles of organic matrix, which will in turn improve the reliability in paleo-proxies and hence accuracy in paleoclimatic reconstructions. This research has provided valuable training for an early-career PI for managing a federally-funded research project for the first time and scientific community outreach. Furthermore, this research has provided partial support for a graduate student to be trained for experimental and analytical work in the laboratory. Two peer-reviewed scientific papers have been published so far and our experimental data have been submitted/archived in EarthChem digital library.
